article.description: Brett Nelson drained seven 3-pointers and scored a season-high 25 points as the fourth-ranked Gators continued the best start in school history with a 70-53 Southeastern Conference victory over Louisiana State.
article.headline: Nelson shoots Gators to 13th straight win with seven 3's
article.linkText: Nelson nails seven 3's in Gators' 13th straight win
article.story:
BATON ROUGE, La. (AP) -- Brett Nelson got his 3-point shooting touch back when Florida really needed it and LSU least expected it.

Nelson hit seven 3-pointers en route to a season-high 26 points and No. 4 Florida won its 13th straight, 70-53 over LSU on Tuesday night.

LSU coach John Brady said his team's primary defensive goal was
to shut down the Gators' leading scorer, Matt Bonner, who was
averaging nearly 15 points. The Tigers forced Bonner into
committing two quick fouls and held him to only three points.

Nelson was only 7-of-27 in Florida's first five SEC games and
had barely hit 25 percent of his 3-point attempts on the season.

"We couldn't guard Florida on everything. We had to give something up,'' said Brady, who made note of Nelson's previous shooting struggles.

The timing of Nelson's shooting made it even more devastating.
His fourth 3-pointer followed two consecutive 3s by Collis Temple
which had pulled LSU within 41-36 with 13:07 left in the game.
	
Nelson then hit two straight from long range after LSU had pulled within seven, giving Florida (17-2, 6-0 Southeastern Conference) a 57-44 lead with 4:46 left. LSU (12-6, 1-5), which had knocked off the last two Top Ten teams it had hosted -- then-No. 1 Arizona and then-No. 7 Mississippi State -- would never get close again.

Florida coach Billy Donovan said he hadn't worried too much about Nelson's shooting because he was playing hard, creating offense for other players and had been solid defensively.

"Everyone keeps saying, 'Is this Brett Neslon's breakout game?'
And I really don't look at it that way,'' Donovan said. "As long
as Brett's doing things that helps us win, I can leave him on the
floor. Tonight he obviously shot very well and gave us a huge lift.''

Nelson, who finished 7-for-11 from 3-point range, said hitting three 3s in the first half gave him confidence to keep firing away.

"In the second half I felt pretty good there. I hit a couple wide-open ones, and after you hit the open ones you can hit tougher ones,'' Nelson said. "I just got open looks and I was fortunate that my shot was going in.''

Florida would tie its longest ever winning streak, set last year, with a victory on Saturday at home against Arkansas.

Temple scored 21 points, including four 3-pointers, to lead LSU, which has lost four in a row, including two straight at home, where the Tigers started 11-0. He scored his 1,000th career point on a free throw with 51 seconds left in the game.

Ronald Dupree had 20 points and nine rebounds for LSU, which
sorely missed production from senior guard Torris Bright, who
didn't score for the first time in his career and was averaging 11
points this season. Center Jaime Lloreda, who averaged nearly 13
points coming in, was held to three and did not score in the first
half, but did have 11 rebounds.

David Lee had 11 rebounds for Florida, while Bonell Colas and
Matt Walsh each had nine points in a Florida attack that was
balanced other except for Nelson. Lee said his production was
limited by cramping in the second half.

LSU shot well below its nearly 50 percent average, hitting only
33 percent from the field. LSU was only 5-of-27 from 3-point range,
well below its 35.7 percent average. Florida hit 43 percent of its
field goals and was 8-of-22 from 3-point range.

"I think the stage was set for LSU to beat us tonight, with
everything that they were going through and I think that we had a
lot to overcome,'' Donovan said. "If you had told me we were going
to win by 17 under the circumstances at hand -- with Bonner in foul
trouble and David cramping ... with everything we were going
against, our guys really stepped up tonight and played well.''

Florida started slowly, hitting three of its first 10 shots. LSU
went up 9-4, but the Tigers then went five minutes without a point,
while Florida began a 20-3 run.

   Nelson had two 3-pointers during the run and Lee finished it by
following a miss with a dunk to give the Gators a 24-12 lead. LSU
missed the front end of three 1-and-1s during the run, with Lloreda
missing two.

Temple broke the LSU drought with a 3 that started a 7-2 run and
brought the Tigers within 26-19, but Florida came back with a 3
from nearly 30 feet by Anthony Roberson and another 3-pointer by
Nelson as the Gators took a 33-21 halftime lead.

"We knew all a long that it was just a matter of time before
Brett started hitting shots,'' Walsh said. "He's been hitting
those in practice. We knew how good a shooter he was.''
